# Recap: Nations, states and nation-states

\begin{itemize}
\small
  \item Nations
  \begin{itemize}
    \item "Imagined Communities" (Benedict Anderson 1983)
    \item Top-down and/or bottom-up construction of shared identity
  \end{itemize}
  \vspace{0.1cm}
  \item States
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Political autorities/entities with the legitimacy to use coercive power (Charles Tilly 1990)
    \item Centralizred armed forces (military and police), bureaucracy, and "infrastructure" (e.g., transportation)
    \item Taking various forms in history and contemporary era
  \end{itemize}
  \vspace{0.1cm}
  \item Nations and states do not always align, and when they do not
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Nations without states: armed conflicts and secession/independent movement; "Wars in the Balkans" in the 1990s
    \item Multi-ethnic/nation states: plural societies as put by Arend Lijphart 1977; Northern Ireland after the 1997 Good Friday Agreement
  \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}

# Comparing constitutions like a legal scholar

\begin{itemize}
  \item Ideology (e.g., the Federalist Papers)
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \item Formats: Cofied versus uncodified? Written versus unwritten (norms)?
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \item Texts
  \vspace{0.1cm}
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Length: Lengthy or succinnt?
    \item Substance: Principles or details?
    \item Wording: Simple or sophisticated? 
  \end{itemize}
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \item Rules for changes: Hard/strong versus soft/weak? How difficult it is to change some parts of or the whole consttitution? (see Abramson and Barber 2019)
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \item Key inquries: Coming up with a "perfect" constitutional law
\end{itemize}

# Comparing constitutions like a political scientist

\begin{itemize}
\small
  \item Varieties of constitutional democracy
  \vspace{0.1cm}
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Executive system: presidential versus parliamentary
    \item Electoral system: majoritarian/plurality, PR and mixed-member (and the resulting party system)
    \item Legislative system: uni- or bi-cameral
    \item Central-local relations: federal, unitary and decentralized
  \end{itemize}
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \item Key inquries: Underlying power dynamics driving the "creation" as well as the "practice"
  \vspace{0.1cm}
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Power concentration and dispersion (Lijphart 1999; Powell 2000), and the resulting design of judiciary
    \item Rigid or adapatative constitutions (Levitsky and Murillo 2009)
  \end{itemize}
  \vspace{0.1cm}
  \item Two visions of democracy: Westminster Model versus Concensus Model as a response to "Madison's dilemma"
\end{itemize}

# Supreme courts and constitutional review

\begin{itemize}
  \item Judiciary in the constitution organizes relations between the executive and legislative branches of government:
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \begin{itemize}
    \item \textbf{Parliamentary supremacy}: a principle according to which judges' decisions remain subordinate to decisions of the legislative majority (e.g., UK before 2009)
    \item \textbf{Judicial review}: the ability of a country's high court to invalidate laws the legislature has enacted by declaring them unconstitutional (e.g., USA, Germany and UK after 2009)
  \end{itemize}
  \vspace{0.3cm}
  \item What explans the adoption of either principle? What is the "politics" behind the operation of these principles?
\end{itemize}

# "Why Govts Call A State of Emergency" (Bj√∏rnskov and Voigt 2018)

\begin{itemize}
  \item Countries w/o constitutionalized emergency provisions declare states of emergency (SoE) significantly more often than those that have them
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \item When the cost to declare SoE is low, governments will do so more frequently for natural disasters (but not for political "turmoils")
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \item Large natural disasters are more likely to lead to an official SOE when the legislature holds more power
  \vspace{0.2cm}
  \item Takeaway lessons
  \vspace{0.1cm}
  \begin{itemize}
    \item Constitutioal provisions (as institutional checks) matter
    \item Not all SoEs are idential
  \end{itemize}
\end{itemize}
